channel.title: @hyperdbg - Telegram group archive
channel.description: Public archive of HyperDbg Telegram messages.

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-12-15 18:18:19+00:00 (#8413)
item.description: There are indeed separate page tables on Linux and Windows, and that's the reason you trap CR3 writes in the hypervisor as well

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-12-15 18:17:18+00:00 (#8412)
item.description: But my take is hypervisor doesn't know anything about the guest, whether it is linux, dos or etc. Hypervisor's purpose is to virtualize the execution environment.

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-12-15 18:15:38+00:00 (#8411)
item.description: Oh, that's a question for the author then, hehe

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-12-15 18:10:51+00:00 (#8410)
item.description:
[discord] <jamlee7879> I'm currently reading "hypervisor-from-scratch-part-4". The architecture diagram of the shadow page table in it doesn't quite match the Linux memory management logic that I knew before, so I'm a bit confused.
My understanding is the same as that shown in this diagram. https://www.ryanstan.com/mmu-virtualization-shadow-page-tables.html https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1317916799718785165/shadow-page-tables-diagram.png?ex=67606d2a&is=675f1baa&hm=2465f1cf56627b2a46e465caf83e28c81d27045ecfaa3609840c7d26023dabf0&

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-12-15 18:03:18+00:00 (#8409)
item.description: I don't know which material you're researching, but it looks like a description of a hypervisor for a pre-EPT era. Hypervisor would trap page faults and mask CR3 register, so that it would replace needed pages for the guest OS on the fly. Indeed, you would have to mask all related page tables (for every related process). However, it's more like an implementation detail, that's why it's probably out of scope for your material.

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-12-15 17:58:06+00:00 (#8408)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> Many diagrams are drawn in this way, but I don't understand why only one page table is drawn for the guest. Clearly, there should be multiple page tables (one for each process). https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1317913591650713721/703cb802dfdf67ea4295e3fdd8d6d9fe.png?ex=67606a2d&is=675f18ad&hm=eca03a1625753c826ceccd0c301c338ab31ceb44e9db6e09fac291f1a87e4e46&

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-12-15 17:54:57+00:00 (#8407)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> In Linux, each process has its own page table. However, according to the concept of shadow page tables, it seems that there is only one page table for the guest. This seems very strange. https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1317912800395399219/shadow-page-tables-1.png?ex=67606971&is=675f17f1&hm=1a24bfdbcdcae67675e731575ebe01ef151b97f61fd90ba7a7f6eb7c27301627&

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-12-13 22:13:55+00:00 (#8404)
item.description: Great. Thanks for fixing it.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-12-13 22:13:42+00:00 (#8403)
item.description: Merged! üëç

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-12-13 17:31:02+00:00 (#8402)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> Checked in successfully for 'hypervisor-from-scratch-part-2' https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1317182006190280714/image.png?ex=675dc0d6&is=675c6f56&hm=91e6ccffd96bea431c7a7874768e590b9379d3dcdb86319ac7097608203ae61b&

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-12-11 17:03:02+00:00 (#8397)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> it works for me. my win version is 10.0.16299 https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1316450184007385099/image.png?ex=675b1746&is=6759c5c6&hm=519cbc2fcbf829fa164e17084e0366b7e0c0e5074fb3be8a911d086e4e590392&

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-12-11 16:59:12+00:00 (#8395)
item.description:
[discord] <jamlee7879> @HyperDbgBridge Is Rayanfam in the group? Things aren't working properly here. The registry entries for DbgView aren't working properly either. It took me about an hour to figure out the correct way to do it. Here's what you should do: Save the following content as dgbview.reg. Double-click on dgbview.reg.
``` Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00
[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Debug Print Filter] "DEFAULT"=dword:0000000f ``` https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1316449218633928724/image.png?ex=675b1660&is=6759c4e0&hm=828c61954ef4c4123a50b78220337f9999819a81292ad551763e8655a98fcedb&

HyperDbg v0.11 is released! ‚ú®
This version comes with bug fixes, improvements, and two new commands for viewing Local APIC (XAPIC/X2APIC) and IO APIC.
Big shoutout to Bj√∂rn Ruytenberg for joining the team for bringing PCIe support to HyperDbg!
https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/releases/tag/v0.11.0
Check it out: https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/extension-commands/apic

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-29 10:07:34+00:00 (#8380)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> Next, I'll go on to read "Hypervisor From Scratch" in more depth.

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-29 10:05:23+00:00 (#8379)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> Yes, this is exactly the answer I was looking for. Actually, I asked ChatGPT to write example code like this before, but I can't be 100% sure that the MSR registers are shareable. I didn't have a deep enough understanding of virtualization before. Thank you. You've been a great help.

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-11-29 09:57:38+00:00 (#8378)
item.description: It‚Äôs the same cpu all the time, it just has different modes of operation. Depending on the mode of execution the CPU has either additional features or otherwise a reduced set of them. VMX root mode pretty much just allows the execution of VMX instructions. VMX guest mode allows auxiliary control structures (like vmcs) to back up its execution. The whole idea of trapping various events in the guest mode is to allow the hypervisor to properly emulate the platform. MSRs for example are shared between all modes, but you don‚Äôt want the guest to mess with MsRs that could affect VMX root mode, right? That‚Äôs why you have the ability to intercept them and manually handle in the root mode. If that‚Äôs your question.

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-29 09:44:55+00:00 (#8377)
item.description:
[discord] <jamlee7879> Yes, I've briefly read through the "Hypervisor From Scratch" series, but I didn't quite understand it. I can't imagine what a bluepill style hypervisor program is like. Here's what I know: 1. When the Virtual Machine Monitor (VMM) enters the VMX (Virtual Machine eXtensions) mode, it has already set up the conversions for the Virtual Machine Control Structure (VMCS) and Extended Page Table (EPT). 2. The state of the CPU that enters the operation will be stored in the VMCS. At this time, the virtualized CPU is being used. 3. Then it exits the VMX mode. The code runs on the physical CPU again.
The CPU running in VT (Virtualization Technology) and the physical CPU are like two completely different worlds. Why is it related to the MSR (Model Specific Register) hook? I must have missed some crucial information.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-29 08:49:14+00:00 (#8375)
item.description:
If you're curious about these topics, you might be interested in checking Hypervisor From Scratch series which describes how HyperDbg works internally:
https://rayanfam.com/tutorials/

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-29 08:48:01+00:00 (#8374)
item.description: Generally, VT-x is consist of some instructions, which gives you (VMM) the ability to control critical CPU components (like memory, interrupts, IO ports, PCIe bars) by triggering VM-exits.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-29 08:45:10+00:00 (#8373)
item.description: EPT Violation is a form of VM-exit.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-29 08:44:16+00:00 (#8372)
item.description: HyperDbg is a bluepill style hypervisor, which means it virtualizes and already running system. Think of it as a system that is running and then you virtualize all system resources (starting from kernel).

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-28 18:21:35+00:00 (#8371)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> https://tenor.com/view/hot-summer-scary-scared-creepy-gif-17494278817868935582

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-28 18:20:47+00:00 (#8370)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> How does an EPT violation trigger a VM Exit event? Windows isn't running in a virtual machine. Can't it be handled directly in a driver?

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-28 18:19:16+00:00 (#8369)
item.description: [discord] <jamlee7879> Hi. What's the working principle of the EPT classic hook? I really can't figure out why a Windows running on a physical machine can also trigger an EPT violation.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-24 15:36:25+00:00 (#8366)
item.description: Nope, unfortunately HyperDbg only uses its custom protocol, not gdb stub.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-24 15:35:26+00:00 (#8365)
item.description: Great. üëç

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-24 14:03:03+00:00 (#8364)

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-24 14:02:05+00:00 (#8362)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-23 18:14:37+00:00 (#8361)
item.description: Sure thing. Let me know about the results. If it didn't work, probably there are other options like ignoring exceptions (using the !exception command).

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-23 18:13:05+00:00 (#8360)
item.description: [discord] <adam235513> Ok, I will give it a try tomorrow. Thanks

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-23 18:11:43+00:00 (#8359)
item.description:
If you need to disable intercepting traps (single stepping) like #DB, you could use this command:
test trap off

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-23 18:10:41+00:00 (#8357)
item.description:
You can disable triggering (intercepting breakpoints by HyperDbg) using this command:
test breakpoint off

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-23 18:10:10+00:00 (#8356)
item.description: [discord] <adam235513> Like a page guard is set on the memory page and hyprdbg is catching the exception

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-23 18:09:45+00:00 (#8355)
item.description: [discord] <adam235513> Yes, exactly. After each instruction is executed it breaks. So hyperdbg becomes useless

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-23 18:08:54+00:00 (#8354)
item.description: What do you mean by "breaks HyperDbg"? Is it something like triggering infinite number of breakpoints?

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-23 18:06:52+00:00 (#8353)
item.description: [discord] <adam235513> No, because it directly breaks in HyperDbg even when I don't launch it through hyperdbg. Can modify the code, already compiled it myself

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-23 18:06:20+00:00 (#8352)
item.description: Or another option that you have is putting some hooks in some APIs or system-calls and intercept it this way. It's probably a better approach.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-23 18:05:21+00:00 (#8351)
item.description: It's actually possible but if you could modify the source code (and recompile HyperDbg), but could you run the PE and then attach to it? It would be easier.

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-23 01:52:10+00:00 (#8350)
item.description: [discord] <adam235513> Yeah, it has TLS. Can I disable the behavior? It doesn't have to break at the EP. I can set a breakpoint on one of the Windows APIs

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-22 22:29:20+00:00 (#8349)
item.description: Once you press 'g' it stops at the PE entrypoint, unless there is an anti debugging method (maybe TLS?) that breaks the debugging?

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-11-22 04:48:49+00:00 (#8348)
item.description: [discord] <adam235513> Hi, Im trying to debug a process with anti debug. So I thought I use HyperDbg to avoid being detecting. So when I start the process in the VM HyperDbg will directly break in the process. When I press `g` it will break on the next instruction ... Is there a way to disable the behavior or at least some kind of logging to see why HyperDbg is breaking ? Is it page guard?!

item.title: @333224414 on 2024-11-20 18:19:45+00:00 (#8346)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-20 15:19:42+00:00 (#8342)
item.description:
Two new commands are now documented (and merged to the 'dev' branch) for dumping I/O APIC and Local APIC (in both XAPIC and X2APIC mode). If you want to test it before the official v0.11 release, you can switch to the 'dev' branch.
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/extension-commands/apic https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/extension-commands/ioapic

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 15:04:40+00:00 (#8329)
item.description: Yes, that's right. After I allocated 4G of memory, the problem disappeared

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:59:57+00:00 (#8328)
item.description: Now I will try to allocate more memory

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:59:47+00:00 (#8327)
item.description: That's the reason.

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:59:38+00:00 (#8326)
item.description: Perhaps this is the reason for the problem

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:59:21+00:00 (#8325)
item.description: Allocated 4G to Win11

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:58:59+00:00 (#8324)
item.description: I only allocated 2g to Win10

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:58:28+00:00 (#8323)
item.description: o... you are right

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:58:00+00:00 (#8322)
item.description: Yes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:57:54+00:00 (#8321)
item.description: Once the RAM is full, Windows tries to page-out that page and that's why you get this error. (I assume that you didn't give your virtual machine enough RAM?).

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:57:51+00:00 (#8320)
item.description: That means the page has been replaced?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:56:36+00:00 (#8319)
item.description: So, it seems to be because of Windows paging.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:56:21+00:00 (#8318)
item.description: After some time (around 30 minutes), it started to show the invalid error to me. I checked it with x64dbg as well). I accessed it from x64dbg and the address becomes available in HyperDbg.

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:55:19+00:00 (#8317)
item.description: great

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:54:39+00:00 (#8316)
item.description: Wait, I think I find the error.

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:39:14+00:00 (#8315)
item.description: You have already helped me a lot, thank you for your software, it's great

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:37:49+00:00 (#8314)
item.description: But, probably, it would take a while. So, meanwhile you could enjoy using HyperDbg on your Win11, meanwhile I try to understand what goes wrong with this command in the Windows 10.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-11-13 14:36:39+00:00 (#8313)
item.description: That's super weird. I have a Win 10 here, I'm gonna test on it too.

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:36:39+00:00 (#8312)

item.title: @6695510551 on 2024-11-13 14:36:11+00:00 (#8310)
